subject: Add "GenerationInUse" and "GenerationSupported" to PCIeDevice interface
commitMessage:
Add "GenerationInUse" and "GenerationSupported" to PCIeDevice interface

Add PCIeDevice properties "GenerationInUse" and "GenerationSupported"
then let managerment APIs like redfish can expose the information.

New property:
GenerationInUse    : The PCIe interface generation in use by the device
GenerationSupported: The maximum PCIe generation supported by the device

Dbus Sample output:
NAME                                TYPE      SIGNATURE RESULT/VALUE     FLAGS
[...]
xyz.openbmc_project.PCIe.Device     interface -         -                -
.DeviceType                         property  s         "SingleFunction" emits-change
.Function0ClassCode                 property  s         "0x060400"       emits-change
[...]
.GenerationInUse                    property  s         "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.PCIeSlot.Generations.Gen2"           emits-change

Signed-off-by: Spencer Ku <Spencer.Ku@quantatw.com>
Change-Id: Ie1bf12a703dc85c3670487b146fb62f0dbae9908

In the future, if someone appears to have abandoned working on a commit, feel free to take it over for them (after talking to them or not getting any response).  It is better to start with work that has already been reviewed partially.  You can add your own S-O-B to someone else's commit.
Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 7fd1de390723586dd94bd0b0119f8273d20ff46e by Patrick Williams

Can you adjust your 'git config' to ensure this is a legal name?  (Maybe this is how you would specify your name in a legal document, but I assume based on your email address that it is "Spencer Ku" instead.)
Thank you for the suggestion. "Spencer Ku" is correct. Already fixed my git config.

Is this intended to be the "currently trained speed" or the "maximum speed supported by the device"?  Your wording says "in use" but I'm not sure if that is always detectable.  Isn't it useful to also know the maximum speed the device could have trained?

Is it also useful to support Lanes?  Take a look at PCIeSlot and see if there is information from the slot that should also end up on the device.

Yes, we are trying to implement "currently trained speed" of device. I think both "Max Speed Supported" or "Lanes" are also the useful PCIe device information. The reason why I only update "PCIeType" is that we are working on implementing this property on bmcweb and peci-pcie and both are under reviewing. The detail can be find in topic "PcieType".
Inventory/Item/PCIeSlot.interface.yaml already has this enumeration.
Replace to use the enumeration which provide by PCIeSlot.

I don't think this is named well then.  Is "Speed" what you're looking for?
Or "TrainedGen[eration]"?  "PCIeType" would imply to me the maximum speed or design type of the card, not the current speed in use, because often times different generations have a different mechanical edge design.

I'm so sorry i didn't make myself clear. I think "negotiated link speed" is what i want to mean here. In PCIe Device, we can obtain negotiated link speed from "Current Link Speed"(CLS)" field in link status register(LNKSTS). I confuse with the field name. In my opinion, the information between CLS and PCIe type is the same. Please correct me if there is any mistake. 

The description of PCIeType from Redfish PCIeDevice schemas:
PCIeType:
"This property shall contain the negotiated PCIe interface version in use by this device."

The description of CLS:
"This field indicates the negotiated link speed of the given PCIe* link."

The description of LNKSTS:
"The PCIe* link status register provides information on the status of the PCIe* link
such as negotiated width, training, and so on."
Hm... Once it supposed to be `TrainedGen` (i.e. actually used here), shouldn't it go to `xyz.openbmc_project.State.Decorator.xxx` instead?
Note the actual negotiated speed can vary due to device policy eg for power savings (along with device width).

@Spencer - I think the primary issue here is with the name.  I understand Redfish has that name but it is a pretty poor description of what is being modeled.  I'd like to see something more appropriate even though it doesn't align with what Redfish chose.

Actually, I want to know is this actually expected to be the speed in use, the trained speed, or the speed supported?  My point is the former can be quite dynamic on some cards.

Note that the upstream port and downstream port can limit the speed; and somtimes the upstream can be limited because the backplane or other interconnect doesn't support what the silicon supports.

> @Patrick - Thank you, I understand the problem here. I think "TrainedGen" looks good for me?

Probably want to spell out "TrainedGeneration"

Other alternatives (but I don't have a strong opinion here):
"GenerationInUse"
which could be a nice counter to GenerationSupported when we add it in the future.

Agreed, redfish picked a mediocre name here, but they also have different namespace scoping rules than we have on dbus, so they have to explicitly put "PCIe" in the name, which explains some of this.


> Actually, I want to know is this actually expected to be the speed in use, the trained speed, or the speed supported?

If this is following Redfish it's for the trained version.  From the spec:

"The version of the PCIe specification in use by this device"

Ok if that's the spec it is what it is.   Just something that could change frequently, and didn't want to impose an unnecessary update burden.
Ack from me will leave it to @Patrick.
Thanks Ed's suggestion, I think both name are suitable here. In my opinion, how about rename "PCIeType" to "GenerationInUse", and rename "MaxPCIeType" to "GenerationSupported"?

Not related to this particular commit but I don't like this interface from beginning. 
I would suggest to refactor this `FunctionXXX` into separate interface like `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.PCIeFunction` and make each function as subnode of `PCIeDevice` like this:
```
└─/xyz
  └─/xyz/openbmc_project
    └─/xyz/openbmc_project/PCIe
      └─/xyz/openbmc_project/PCIe/S0B5D0
        ├─/xyz/openbmc_project/PCIe/S0B5D0/func0
        ├─/xyz/openbmc_project/PCIe/S0B5D0/func1
        └─/xyz/openbmc_project/PCIe/S0B5D0/func2
```
